Situation1: They notice a few pool chairs are slightly misaligned but still usable.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A social media post about your cause is currently going viral, and now is the perfect moment to add a comment with more information.
Story: I was making my rounds at the pool, the sun glinting off the water, when I noticed a few pool chairs out of place. They weren’t blocking any paths, but I knew part of my job as a lifeguard was to keep everything orderly and safe. I could already hear my supervisor’s voice in my head: “Attention to detail matters.” As I moved to fix them, my phone buzzed in my pocket. I glanced at the screen—my activist group’s latest post was exploding online. This was the moment we’d been waiting for, the perfect chance to educate thousands about our cause if I could just add a thoughtful comment now. My heart pounded. If I stopped to type, I’d be neglecting my lifeguard duties, risking a reprimand or worse. But if I ignored the post, I’d miss a rare opportunity to make a real impact. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my full attention, and I stood frozen, torn between the pool chairs and my phone, feeling the pressure mount.
